>> Joyce: Hi, this
is Joyce Farrell.

Let's continue to talk about
the program development cycle.

In the last video you
learned the first step

to developing a computer program
is to understand the problem.

And we talked about the problem
of being able to write a program

where you have a
user type in a value,

the program doubles
the value for the user,
and outputs the answer.

We then talked about planning
the logic to that problem,
and we used 2 tools: a flowchart

and a pseudocode
to show the logic.

The flowchart and the pseudocode
look very similar. Both

start. Both allow a user to
input a value called myNumber.

In both cases you set myAnswer
equal to myNumber times 2

and then you output
myAnswer and stop the program.
After you understand the problem

and plan its logic,
you can write the code
to the computer program.

Writing the code
means putting it

into a computer programming
language such as Visual Basic
or C++ or Java.

For example, here's
some Java code.

It looks confusing at
first because there's dots
and parentheses and semicolons,

but basically what these 3
statements do is get a value

from the keyboard and
store it in myNumber.

The middle statement computes
the value of myAnswer

as myNumber times 2.
This one looks the most

like the flowchart or the
pseudocode statement.

And then the last statement has
some new words and some dots,

but it outputs the
words Answer is
and then the value of myAnswer.

Notice that each Java
statement ends in a semicolon
because that's required in Java.

It's not required in pseudocode
or in a flowchart,

but Java has particular syntax
that you have

to learn before you can
write this program in Java.

In most computer programs,
you would add a prompt

for the user before the input
statement. This one displays
on the screen Enter a number

and then shows 2 little
right-facing arrows

to show the user where
to type in an answer.

A complete Java program would
have many more statements in it.

You can see some statements
before the core part

of this program and
some punctuation after,

but the highlighted
part of the screen shows

that you prompt the
user to enter a number,

you get the number,
you compute myAnswer,

and you output the
value of myAnswer.

Here's the Java
NumberDoubling program

with a mistake purposely
entered into it.
Because you're not familiar

with Java, you might not notice
the mistake right away, but it's

in the last line of code
that displays myAnswer.

I've purposely left off the
semicolon that Java requires
at the end of every statement.
I've purposely made this mistake

because when you type a
program it is very easy

to make a typographical
error, and I want

to show you what happens
when you make one.

After you understand a
problem, plan its logic,

and write the code you're
ready to translate the code.

Translating the code
means using a piece

of software, called a
compiler or an interpreter,

and taking your code in
the programming language

and turning it into machine
language, which is the 1

and 0 circuitry language
inside the computer.

For example, one way to
compile a Java program is to go

to the Command Prompt and
type javac, which stands

for Java Compile, and type
the name of the program.

When you press the Enter key,
in this case, you get a mistake.

It says NumberDoubling.java12
because the mistake happens
to be in line 12 of the program,

and then it says
semicolon expected.

Well, that makes sense because
I told you I purposely left off

the semicolon in order
to generate this mistake.

The error message then
continues with the line

where the mistake is, System.out.println
Answer is myAnswer,

and way over on the right
there's a little carrot pointing

to the spot where Java
noticed the mistake.

If you understand this error
message, you can go back

into your program
and add the semicolon
and now the problem is fixed.

You might then return
to the Command Prompt,

type the compiling
statement again, press Enter,

and this time there
are no error messages

and you have a successful
compile of the program.

The program has successfully
been translated
into machine language.

After you have translated the
code, you can test the program,

then put the program
into production,
and then maintain the program.

We'll talk about these next
3 steps in the next video.
Thanks for watching.
